questions.text: The windkessel effect is seen in___.
questions.solution:
The windkessel effect is seen in large elastic vessels.

The aorta, the pulmonary artery, and their major branches have a large amount of elastin in their walls. Hence, they have a high elastic recoil effect. This property of elastic recoil is called windkessel effect (windkessel is a German word for the elastic reservoir).

This recoil of the vessels that have been stretched during systole helps to propel the blood forward during diastole thus maintaining a continuous flow throughout the cardiac cycle.

Related Pearl: Types of Blood Vessels

Types of Blood Vessels

TYPES

FEATURES

Windkessel vessels

Aorta and large arteries.

Abundant elastic tissues in the inner and external elastic lamina

Shows elastic recoil (windkessel effect) when stretched

Resistance vessels

Arterioles

Have less elastic tissue and lot of smooth muscle (maximum wall thickness to lumen ratio)

Major site of resistance to blood flow

Exchange vessels

Capillaries

Do not have smooth muscles, consist of single layer of endothelial cells surrounded by a basement membrane

Site of exchange of nutrients, water and gases

Types

  • Continuous- brain, retina (have tight junctions)
  • Fenestrated- glomeruli, choroid plexus
  • Sinusoidal- liver, spleen

Blood flow regulation is by contraction and relaxation of the arterioles and precapillary sphincter

Capacitance vessels

Venules & veins

Thin-walled, easily distensible (maximum percentage of blood volume)

Shunt vessels

AV anastomoses

Have thick muscular walls with rich innervation

Found in – finger tips, ear lobes

questions.text: The greatest total cross-sectional area in the circulatory system is of _____.
questions.solution:
The greatest total cross-sectional area in the circulatory system is of the capillaries.

The total cross-sectional area is minimum for the aorta.

questions.text: Largest percentage of blood volume in the circulatory system is in _____.
questions.solution:
Largest percentage of blood volume in the circulatory system is in veins.

Vessels and Percentage of Total Blood Volume

VESSELS

% OF TOTAL BLOOD VOLUME

Heart

12

Pulmonary circulation

18

Aorta

2

Artery

8

Arteriole

1

Capillary

5

Venule, vein, vena cava

54

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct regarding capillaries?

choices.text: Have a single layer of cells bounding the lumen

questions.solution: Capillaries contain 5% of the total blood volume.

questions.text: In the circulatory system, the highest velocity of blood flow is in the _____.
questions.solution:
In circulatory system, the highest velocity of blood flow is in the aorta.

  • The velocity of blood flow is inversely proportional to vascular cross-sectional area.

v= velocity
F= blood flow through the vessel
A=vascular cross-sectional area

  • Aorta has the least cross sectional area (4.5 cm2) and capillaries have the maximum cross sectional area (4500 cm2). Thus, under resting conditions, the velocity is highest in aorta and least in capillaries.

questions.text: The largest compliance in the circulatory system is of ____.
questions.solution:
The largest compliance in the circulatory system is of veins.

Vascular compliance/capacitance is the total quantity of blood that can be stored in a given portion of the circulation for each mmHg pressure rise.
Vascular Compliance = distensibility X volume.
The compliance of a systemic vein is about 24 times that of its corresponding artery because it is about 8 times as distensible and has a volume about 3 times as artery (8 × 3 = 24).

Related Pearl: Types of Blood Vessels

choices.text: Sum of kinetic energy of flow and pressure energy is constant
Low tones produces maximum stimulation at the apex of cochlea
Magnitude of sensation felt is proportional to the intensity of stimulus
Force of contraction is proportional to stretch of the cardiac muscle

questions.solution:
The Bernoulli's theorem states that in a tube or blood vessel, the sum of the kinetic energy of flow and pressure energy is constant.

Other options:

  • Option B: Travelling wave theory (Theories of hearing): Low tones produce maximum stimulation at the apex of the cochlea.
  • Option C: Weber—Fechner law: The magnitude of sensation felt is proportional to the log of the intensity of the stimulus.
  • Option D: Frank—Starling law of the heart: Force of contraction is proportional to stretch of the cardiac muscle.

questions.text: The blood flow through a vessel varies directly with _____
questions.solution:
The blood flow through a vessel varies directly with pressure difference.

The blood flow follows Ohm’s law:

Where,

  • F = Blood flow
  • P = Pressure difference between two ends of the vessel
  • R = Resistance

questions.text: Which of the following increases turbulence in blood flow?

choices.text: Increase in diameter of blood vessel

questions.solution:
Turbulence in blood flow increases with increase in diameter of blood vessel.

The turbulence of flow depends upon Reynold’s number:

Where,
v – velocity of flow – cm/sec
ρ – density of blood
d – diameter of the vessel
μ – viscosity of blood in poise

Reynold’s number

Type of blood flow

<2000

Laminar

2000-3000

Transitional

>3000

Turbulent


Therefore, increase in diameter increases turbulence.

questions.text: The tendency for turbulent flow is greatest in _______.
questions.solution:
The tendency for turbulent flow is greatest in the aorta.
The turbulence of flow depends upon Reynold’s number:

v – velocity of flow – cm/sec
ρ – density of blood
d – diameter of the vessel
μ – viscosity of blood in poise

Reynold’s number

Type of blood flow

<2000

Laminar

2000-3000

Transitional

>3000

Turbulent

In the proximal portions of the aorta and pulmonary artery, Reynold’s number can rise to several thousand during the rapid phase of the ejection, which causes considerable turbulence due to the following:

  • High velocity of blood flow
  • Pulsatile nature of the flow
  • Sudden change in vessel diameter
  • Large vessel diameter

questions.text: The main site of peripheral vascular resistance is ________
questions.solution:
The main site of peripheral vascular resistance is precapillary arterioles.

Poiseuille—Hagen formula explains that small changes in the calibre of vessels cause large changes in total peripheral resistance.

Where,

R=resistance
η=viscosity
L=length of the tube
r=radius of the tube

The resistance varies inversely with the fourth power of radius.

questions.text: The factor favoring filtration at the arterial end of the capillary bed is ____.

choices.text: Increase in hydrostatic pressure of the capillary
Increase in oncotic pressure of the capillary
Decrease in oncotic pressure of the interstitium

questions.solution:
The factor favoring filtration at the arterial end of the capillary bed is the increase in hydrostatic pressure of the capillary.

The rate of filtration at any point along the capillary bed depends on the balance of the Starling forces, which are responsible for fluid movement.

Net filtration pressure = (Pc-Pi)-(πc- πi)

where,

Pc=capillary hydrostatic pressure
Pi=interstitial hydrostatic pressure
πc=capillary colloidal osmotic pressure
πi=interstitial colloidal osmotic pressure

Glomerular filtration rate = k x NFP

where,

k= capillary filtration coefficient

NFP= Net filtration pressure

Related Pearl: Starling Forces

Starling Forces

Forces favouring filtration

Pc =capillary hydrostatic pressure

πi=interstitial colloidal osmotic pressure

Forces opposing filtration

Pi=interstitial hydrostatic pressure

πc=capillary colloidal osmotic pressure

Factors that increase filtration

↑Pc- caused by increased arterial pressure

↓Pi

↓πc – caused by decreased protein concentration

↑πi – caused by inadequate lymphatic function

questions.text: Which of the following factors tends to increase the lymph flow?
questions.solution:
The factor tend to increase lymph flow is increase in capillary hydrostatic pressure.

Since the lymph is derived from interstitial fluid, any factor that increases interstitial fluid pressure also increases lymph flow provided, the lymph vessels are functioning normally. The factors which increase interstitial fluid pressure include:

  • Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure
  • Increased interstitial fluid colloid osmotic pressure
  • Increased permeability of the capillaries
  • Decreased plasma colloid osmotic pressure

All of the above factors increase the filtration at the capillary-interstitium interface and therefore increase the interstitial fluid volume and pressure.

questions.text: The  coronary blood flow is regulated by ___.
questions.solution:
Coronary blood flow is regulated by adenosine.

Blood flow through the coronary system is regulated mostly by local arteriolar vasodilation in response to the nutritional needs of cardiac muscle.
↑local metabolism → ↓in O2 → breakdown of ATP to form adenosine → vasodilation → ↑local coronary blood flow.

questions.text: True about coronary flow during systole is:

choices.text: No change in flow with systole.
Greater decrease in subendocardium than epicardium.
Greater decrease in epicardium than in subendocardium.

questions.solution:
The coronary blood flow in systole has a greater decrease in subendocardium than epicardium.

The myocardial compression in systole compresses the subendocardial vessels to a greater extent, and the force is sufficiently dissipated in the epicardium to permit some flow in this region throughout the cardiac cycle.

questions.text: Based on the agglutination test shown below, what is the blood group?
questions.solution:
Based on the agglutination test shown in the image, the blood group is O positive.

As agglutination is present only in 'Rh' and not with 'A' and 'B' hence the blood group is O Rh positive.

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy?
questions.solution:
Factor 2 would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy.

Activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X is done by carboxylation of their glutamate residues. This is done by the enzyme γ-glutamyl carboxylase with the reduced form of vitamin K as a co-factor.

This reduced form of vitamin K needs to be constantly recycled back from its oxidized form for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. This enzyme is inhibited by warfarin.

Hence, warfarin indirectly inhibits the γ-carboxylation of vitamin K dependent clotting factors - Factors II, VII, IX, X by directly inhibiting vitamin K epoxide reductase. Thus leading to decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in these factors.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation?
questions.solution:
Inferior vena cava has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation.

The blood gets oxygenated in the placenta and this passes to the umbilical vein. From the umbilical vein, 50% of the blood enters the hepatic circulation and 50% bypasses the liver to enter the inferior vena cava. From here, the blood enters the heart via the right atrium. The right atrium also receives deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava. This mixed blood is distributed to the body via aorta. 

Therefore, inferior vena cava has the highest concentration of oxygen in the fetal circulation.
